title: Proverbs Chapter 14 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Proverbs chapter 14 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Proverbs Chapter 14 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Proverbs Chapter 14.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 14:1, what does a wise woman do?
options: Buildeth her house
Plucketh it down with her hands
Gives away her possessions
Sings songs of praise
questions.correctAnswer: Buildeth her house
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:1 states that every wise woman buildeth her house, contrasting her with the foolish who pluck it down with her hands.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 14:2 say about one who walketh in his uprightness?
options: Feareth the LORD
Is perverse in his ways
Despiseth the LORD
Is proud and boastful
questions.correctAnswer: Feareth the LORD
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:2 explains that he who walketh in his uprightness feareth the LORD, while the perverse despise Him.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 14:5, what will a faithful witness not do?
options: Lie
Tell the truth
Remain silent
Whisper secrets
questions.correctAnswer: Lie
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:5 says a faithful witness will not lie, contrasting with a false witness who utters lies.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 14:7 advise to do when you perceive no lips of knowledge?
options: Go from the presence of a foolish man
Stay and teach him
Argue with him
Ignore the foolishness
questions.correctAnswer: Go from the presence of a foolish man
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:7 advises to go from the presence of a foolish man when you do not perceive knowledge in him.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Proverbs 14:12: 'There is a way which seemeth right unto a man, but the end thereof are the ways of ______.'
options: death
life
peace
joy
questions.correctAnswer: death
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:12 warns that a way may seem right unto a man, but its end leads to death.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 14:15 says the simple man looks well to his going.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:15 states that the simple believeth every word, but the prudent man looks well to his going.

questions.question: What is the attitude of a wise man toward evil according to Proverbs 14:16?
options: Fears and departs from evil
Rages and is confident
Ignores evil
Welcomes evil
questions.correctAnswer: Fears and departs from evil
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:16 says a wise man fears and departs from evil, while a fool rages and is confident.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 14:18, who are crowned with knowledge?
options: The prudent
The simple
The wicked
The proud
questions.correctAnswer: The prudent
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:18 states that the simple inherit folly, but the prudent are crowned with knowledge.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 14:20 say about the poor?
options: The poor is hated even of his own neighbour
The poor have many friends
The poor are always honored
The poor do not need friends
questions.correctAnswer: The poor is hated even of his own neighbour
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:20 states that the poor is hated even of his own neighbour, while the rich has many friends.

questions.question: What is the result for one who oppresseth the poor, according to Proverbs 14:31?
options: He reproacheth his Maker
He is blessed by God
He will become rich
He will be praised
questions.correctAnswer: He reproacheth his Maker
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:31 says he that oppresseth the poor reproacheth his Maker.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 14:34 say exalteth a nation?
options: Righteousness
Wealth
Military power
Sin
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:34 states that righteousness exalteth a nation, but sin is a reproach to any people.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 14:3 says the lips of the wise shall preserve them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:3 contrasts the mouth of the foolish with the lips of the wise, which shall preserve them.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 14:25, what does a true witness do?
options: Delivereth souls
Speaketh lies
Remains silent
Sows discord
questions.correctAnswer: Delivereth souls
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:25 states a true witness delivereth souls, while a deceitful witness speaks lies.

questions.question: What is described as a fountain of life in Proverbs 14:27?
options: The fear of the LORD
Riches
Wisdom
Laughter
questions.correctAnswer: The fear of the LORD
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:27 calls the fear of the LORD a fountain of life to depart from the snares of death.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 14:29 states that he who is hasty of spirit is of great understanding.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:29 says he that is slow to wrath is of great understanding, but he that is hasty of spirit exalteth folly.

medium.title: Proverbs Chapter 14 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Proverbs Chapter 14 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with anger and impatience in their daily relationships. Based on Proverbs 14, what biblical truth would you share about handling anger?
options: He that is soon angry dealeth foolishly
A wise man feareth, and departeth from evil
The heart knoweth his own bitterness
The poor is hated even of his own neighbour
questions.correctAnswer: He that is soon angry dealeth foolishly
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:17 teaches that quick anger leads to foolish behavior, encouraging self-control. Proverbs 14:29 also supports this by valuing slow wrath as understanding. Proverbs 14:16 highlights fearing and departing from evil as wise behavior.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 14 teach about the role of a wise woman in family and home life?
options: Every wise woman buildeth her house
The simple believeth every word
A scorner seeketh wisdom, and findeth it not
The crown of the wise is their riches
questions.correctAnswer: Every wise woman buildeth her house
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:1 shows that wisdom in a woman contributes to building and maintaining a strong home, emphasizing the importance of wise leadership in family life. This is supported by the general theme of prudence and understanding throughout the chapter (Proverbs 14:8,14:33).

questions.question: What counsel does Proverbs 14 give regarding trusting in one's own understanding versus seeking God's guidance?
options: There is a way which seemeth right unto a man, but the end thereof are the ways of death
A faithful witness will not lie
He that oppresseth the poor reproacheth his Maker
The fear of the LORD is a fountain of life
questions.correctAnswer: There is a way which seemeth right unto a man, but the end thereof are the ways of death
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:12 warns against relying solely on human judgment as it can lead to destruction. This is complemented by verses about fearing the Lord (14:2, 14:26, 14:27) and gaining wisdom through understanding (14:6, 14:33).

questions.question: A believer wants to live with integrity and honesty at work. What does Proverbs 14 teach about honesty and witness?
options: A faithful witness will not lie
The simple believeth every word
Where no oxen are, the crib is clean
The evil bow before the good
questions.correctAnswer: A faithful witness will not lie
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:5 directly affirms that honesty preserves integrity. This is supported by Proverbs 14:25 which contrasts true and deceitful witnesses and Proverbs 14:23 highlighting that diligent labor profits, unlike empty talk.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 14 encourage believers to respond to foolishness and folly in others?
options: Go from the presence of a foolish man, when thou perceivest not in him the lips of knowledge
A scorner seeketh wisdom, and findeth it not
The simple inherit folly
The crown of the wise is their riches
questions.correctAnswer: Go from the presence of a foolish man, when thou perceivest not in him the lips of knowledge
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:7 counsels avoidance of foolish company lacking knowledge, promoting discernment. This is complemented by verses about the consequences of folly (14:8, 14:18) and the fruitlessness of seeking wisdom in scorners (14:6).

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 14 teaches that the fear of the LORD provides confidence and a place of refuge for His children.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:26 states that the fear of the LORD is a source of strong confidence and refuge for His children, reflecting the biblical virtue of trusting in God’s protection and guidance.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 14 say about the relationship between labor and profit?
options: In all labour there is profit
The simple believeth every word
The poor is hated even of his own neighbour
The foolishness of fools is folly
questions.correctAnswer: In all labour there is profit
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:23 teaches that diligent labor yields profit, encouraging a good work ethic. This aligns with the broader biblical principle of integrity and diligence in daily life (see Proverbs 14:24, 14:5).

questions.question: According to Proverbs 14, what is the outcome for the wicked and the upright in their homes?
options: The house of the wicked shall be overthrown; but the tabernacle of the upright shall flourish
The poor is hated even of his own neighbour
The crown of the wise is their riches
A sound heart is the life of the flesh
questions.correctAnswer: The house of the wicked shall be overthrown; but the tabernacle of the upright shall flourish
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:11 contrasts the destruction awaiting the wicked’s home with the flourishing of the upright’s dwelling, emphasizing the blessings of righteousness and obedience to God in family life.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 14 advise believers to treat their neighbors, especially those in need?
options: He that despiseth his neighbour sinneth; but he that hath mercy on the poor, happy is he
The evil bow before the good
The poor is hated even of his own neighbour
The simple inherit folly
questions.correctAnswer: He that despiseth his neighbour sinneth; but he that hath mercy on the poor, happy is he
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:21 highlights the sinfulness of despising neighbors and the blessedness of showing mercy on the poor, encouraging love and generosity as key Christian virtues.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "A wise man feareth, and departeth from ____; but the fool rageth, and is confident."
options: evil
sin
pride
trouble
questions.correctAnswer: evil
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:16 teaches that fearing the Lord leads a wise man to avoid evil, while the fool is confident in his folly. This promotes the biblical virtues of humility and obedience.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 14 say about the heart's knowledge of its own sorrow and joy?
options: The heart knoweth his own bitterness; and a stranger doth not intermeddle with his joy
Even in laughter the heart is sorrowful
The simple believeth every word
The wicked is driven away in his wickedness
questions.correctAnswer: The heart knoweth his own bitterness; and a stranger doth not intermeddle with his joy
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:10 reveals that personal sorrows and joys are deeply known by the individual, emphasizing the importance of empathy and personal reflection in spiritual life.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 14 describe the benefits of humility and patience?
options: He that is slow to wrath is of great understanding
The fool rageth, and is confident
A scorner seeketh wisdom, and findeth it not
The wicked at the gates of the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: He that is slow to wrath is of great understanding
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:29 associates patience and slow anger with great understanding, teaching humility and self-control as essential Christian virtues.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 14 teaches that even laughter can conceal sorrow and that mirth may end in heaviness.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:13 shows that outward joy does not always reflect inner peace, reminding believers to seek true contentment through God rather than superficial happiness.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 14, what is the result for those who devise evil compared to those who devise good?
options: Do they not err that devise evil? but mercy and truth shall be to them that devise good
The evil bow before the good
The wicked is driven away in his wickedness
The simple inherit folly
questions.correctAnswer: Do they not err that devise evil? but mercy and truth shall be to them that devise good
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:22 contrasts the failure of evil plans with the blessings of mercy and truth for those who plan good, encouraging integrity and righteousness.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 14 say about the relationship between fear of the LORD and life?
options: The fear of the LORD is a fountain of life, to depart from the snares of death
The simple inherit folly
The crown of the wise is their riches
The heart knoweth his own bitterness
questions.correctAnswer: The fear of the LORD is a fountain of life, to depart from the snares of death
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:27 teaches that fearing the Lord leads to life and protection from death’s dangers, highlighting the importance of reverence and obedience to God.

hard.title: Proverbs Chapter 14 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Proverbs Chapter 14.

questions.question: In Proverbs 14:1, the wise woman is said to build her house. What literary device is primarily used in this verse to convey the contrast between wisdom and folly?
options: Antithesis
Metaphor
Chiasm
Personification
questions.correctAnswer: Antithesis
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:1 uses antithesis by contrasting the wise woman who builds her house with the foolish woman who pulls it down, highlighting the opposing outcomes of wisdom and folly.

questions.question: Proverbs 14:2 highlights the relationship between uprightness and fear of the LORD. Which Old Testament book similarly emphasizes 'fear of the LORD' as foundational to wisdom?
options: Psalm 111
Ecclesiastes
Job
Isaiah
questions.correctAnswer: Psalm 111
questions.explanation: Psalm 111:10 states, 'The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom,' paralleling Proverbs 14:2's emphasis on uprightness and reverence for God as central to wisdom.

questions.question: Proverbs 14:4 uses the imagery of oxen and a crib. What cultural significance did oxen have in the ancient Near East that enhances understanding of this proverb?
options: Oxen represented agricultural strength and productivity
Oxen were symbols of idolatry
Oxen were primarily used for religious sacrifices
Oxen signified royal authority
questions.correctAnswer: Oxen represented agricultural strength and productivity
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, oxen were essential for plowing and agricultural work, so their strength was linked to prosperity, as Proverbs 14:4 suggests by contrasting a clean crib without oxen to the increase gained through their strength.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 14:5, what is the distinguishing characteristic of a faithful witness compared to a false witness?
options: A faithful witness will not lie, but a false witness will utter lies
A faithful witness speaks sparingly, but a false witness is verbose
A faithful witness judges fairly, but a false witness judges harshly
A faithful witness is silent, but a false witness speaks boldly
questions.correctAnswer: A faithful witness will not lie, but a false witness will utter lies
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:5 explicitly states that a faithful witness does not lie, while a false witness utters lies, emphasizing integrity versus deceit.

questions.question: Proverbs 14:6 contrasts the scorner and the one who understands. Which New Testament teaching reflects a similar theme about seeking wisdom and understanding?
options: James 1:5 - Asking God for wisdom
Matthew 5:3 - Blessed are the poor in spirit
Romans 12:2 - Be transformed by the renewing of your mind
Ephesians 6:10 - Be strong in the Lord and in the strength of His might
questions.correctAnswer: James 1:5 - Asking God for wisdom
questions.explanation: James 1:5 encourages believers to ask God for wisdom, reflecting Proverbs 14:6's distinction that understanding leads to knowledge while scorners do not find wisdom.

questions.question: Proverbs 14:12 warns that a way may seem right to a man but ends in death. Which biblical narrative exemplifies this principle through a character's misguided path?
options: King Saul's reign and downfall
David's kingship
Joseph's rise in Egypt
Moses leading Israel
questions.correctAnswer: King Saul's reign and downfall
questions.explanation: King Saul often made decisions that seemed right to him but ultimately led to his rejection by God and death, illustrating the warning in Proverbs 14:12 about the deceptive nature of self-guided paths.

questions.question: In Proverbs 14:15, the simple believe every word, but the prudent man looks well to his going. What Hebrew root word underlies the concept of 'prudent' and what does it imply?
options: בִּינָה (binah) - understanding and discernment
חָכְמָה (chochmah) - wisdom
דַּעַת (da'at) - knowledge
עָרוּם (arum) - shrewdness
questions.correctAnswer: בִּינָה (binah) - understanding and discernment
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word בִּינָה (binah) conveys understanding or discernment, fitting the prudent man's careful consideration described in Proverbs 14:15.

questions.question: Proverbs 14:17 says that he who is soon angry deals foolishly. Which literary parallelism is used here between anger and folly?
options: Synonymous parallelism
Antithetic parallelism
Synthetic parallelism
Chiastic parallelism
questions.correctAnswer: Synonymous parallelism
questions.explanation: The verse employs synonymous parallelism by repeating the idea that quick anger leads to foolish actions, reinforcing the connection between the two.

questions.question: Proverbs 14:18 states that the simple inherit folly, but the prudent are crowned with knowledge. Which New Testament passage echoes this theme of wisdom versus folly?
options: 1 Corinthians 1:18 - The foolishness of the cross
Philippians 4:8 - Think on things that are true and noble
James 3:17 - Wisdom from above
Colossians 2:8 - Beware of philosophy
questions.correctAnswer: James 3:17 - Wisdom from above
questions.explanation: James 3:17 contrasts earthly and heavenly wisdom, emphasizing knowledge and prudence akin to Proverbs 14:18's portrayal of prudence being crowned with knowledge.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 14:20, what social dynamic does the proverb reveal about the poor and the rich in their communities?
options: The poor is hated even by his own neighbor, but the rich has many friends
The rich is despised, but the poor is honored
Both poor and rich are equally respected
The poor has many friends, but the rich is isolated
questions.correctAnswer: The poor is hated even by his own neighbor, but the rich has many friends
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:20 reflects a social reality in ancient Near Eastern culture where poverty often led to social rejection, while wealth attracted companionship and favor.

questions.question: Proverbs 14:23 contrasts labor and talk. How does this relate to the biblical principle found in Ecclesiastes about meaningful work?
options: Work produces profit, while empty talk leads to poverty
Talking leads to wisdom, while work is meaningless
Both work and talk are equally valuable
Talking is better than labor in gaining wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Work produces profit, while empty talk leads to poverty
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:23 teaches that diligent labor yields profit, aligning with Ecclesiastes 5:12 which values meaningful work over mere words or vanity.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 14:27 describes the fear of the LORD as a source of life that helps avoid death's traps.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:27 states, 'The fear of the LORD is a fountain of life, to depart from the snares of death,' confirming that reverence for God preserves life and prevents deadly pitfalls.

questions.question: Proverbs 14:29 states that he who is slow to wrath is of great understanding. What Hebrew word for 'understanding' is used here, and how is it significant?
options: תְּבוּנָה (tevunah) - insight and prudence
חָכְמָה (chochmah) - wisdom
דַּעַת (da'at) - knowledge
מַשְׂכִּיל (maskil) - enlightened
questions.correctAnswer: תְּבוּנָה (tevunah) - insight and prudence
questions.explanation: The word תְּבוּנָה (tevunah) refers to insight and prudence, underscoring the mature self-control praised in Proverbs 14:29.

questions.question: What theme in Proverbs 14:34 about righteousness and sin reflects the covenant blessings and curses found in Deuteronomy?
options: Righteousness exalts a nation, but sin brings reproach
Righteousness leads to wealth, but sin leads to poverty
Righteousness causes isolation, but sin brings community
Righteousness brings sorrow, but sin brings joy
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness exalts a nation, but sin brings reproach
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:34 echoes Deuteronomy’s covenant themes where obedience and righteousness bring blessing and exaltation, while sin brings shame and reproach to the people.

questions.question: Proverbs 14:35 contrasts the king's favor and wrath. How does this reflect the ancient Near Eastern view of royal authority and servant responsibility?
options: Wise servants gain royal favor; those causing shame incur wrath
All servants are treated equally regardless of behavior
Royal favor is given to the strongest warrior
Wrath is only directed at foreign enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Wise servants gain royal favor; those causing shame incur wrath
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, a king's favor was crucial and often given to wise and loyal servants, while those who brought shame faced the king's wrath, as Proverbs 14:35 illustrates.

theological.title: Proverbs Chapter 14 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Proverbs Chapter 14 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 14:1, what is the primary difference between a wise woman and a foolish woman regarding her household?
options: The wise woman builds her house, the foolish plucks it down with her hands
The wise woman ignores her household, the foolish manages it well
The wise woman seeks wealth, the foolish despises it
The wise woman fears God, the foolish is prideful
questions.correctAnswer: The wise woman builds her house, the foolish plucks it down with her hands
questions.explanation: Proverbs 14:1 teaches that wisdom leads to building and establishing the household, reflecting God's design for order and stewardship (Genesis 2:18-25; Ephesians 5:22-33; 1 Timothy 5:14; Titus 2:3-5). The foolish woman destroys what should be nurtured, illustrating sin's destructive power (James 1:5-8).

questions.question: What does Proverbs 14:2 indicate about the relationship between uprightness and the fear of the LORD?
options: Walking in uprightness means fearing the LORD, perverseness means despising Him
Uprightness leads to riches, perverseness leads to poverty
Fearing the LORD causes perverseness, uprightness causes pride
Uprightness is unrelated to fearing the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Walking in uprightness means fearing the LORD, perverseness means despising Him
questions.explanation: The verse highlights the theological truth that fearing God is linked to righteous living, while perverseness reveals rebellion (Psalm 34:9; Proverbs 9:10; Ecclesiastes 12:13; Isaiah 33:6; Romans 1:18-32). Fear of the LORD is foundational for salvation and sanctification.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 14:3, how do the lips of the wise function in contrast to the foolish?
options: Lips of the wise preserve them, lips of the foolish are a rod of pride
Lips of the wise bring destruction, lips of the foolish bring peace
Lips of the wise speak lies, lips of the foolish tell truth
Lips of the wise boast, lips of the foolish are humble
questions.correctAnswer: Lips of the wise preserve them, lips of the foolish are a rod of pride
questions.explanation: Wisdom in speech protects and preserves life (Proverbs 10:31; Ephesians 4:29; James 1:19-20), while folly expressed in pride leads to judgment (Proverbs 16:18; Isaiah 2:12; 1 Peter 5:5). The tongue can build up or destroy, reflecting the heart's condition (Matthew 12:34-37).

questions.question: What does Proverbs 14:5 teach about the nature of a faithful witness compared to a false witness?
options: A faithful witness will not lie, a false witness will utter lies
A faithful witness always agrees with others, a false witness disagrees
A faithful witness is silent, a false witness speaks
A faithful witness deceives, a false witness tells truth
questions.correctAnswer: A faithful witness will not lie, a false witness will utter lies
questions.explanation: This verse affirms the biblical principle of truthfulness required in testimony (Exodus 20:16; Deuteronomy 19:15-21; John 8:44; Ephesians 4:25; Revelation 21:8). Faithful witnesses uphold justice, while false witnesses participate in sin and injustice.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 14:6, what is the difference between a scorner and one who has understanding regarding wisdom?
options: A scorner seeks wisdom but does not find it; knowledge is easy to the understanding
A scorner finds wisdom easily; the understanding cannot find knowledge
Both the scorner and the understanding find wisdom equally
Neither the scorner nor the understanding find wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: A scorner seeks wisdom but does not find it; knowledge is easy to the understanding
questions.explanation: The scorner mocks or rejects true wisdom and therefore cannot obtain it, while the understanding readily gains knowledge (Proverbs 1:22; Psalm 14:1; Job 12:12; James 3:13-17; 1 Corinthians 1:18-25). This highlights the necessity of humility and teachability.

questions.question: What instruction does Proverbs 14:7 give regarding interaction with foolish people?
options: Go from the presence of a foolish man when he lacks knowledge
Stay and correct the foolish man at all times
Ignore wisdom and follow the foolish man
Engage in disputes with the foolish man
questions.correctAnswer: Go from the presence of a foolish man when he lacks knowledge
questions.explanation: This verse teaches prudent separation from folly to avoid harm (Psalm 1:1; 1 Corinthians 15:33; 2 Timothy 2:22; Proverbs 13:20; Ecclesiastes 7:6). Avoiding foolish influences protects one's spiritual and moral wellbeing.

questions.question: Proverbs 14:12 warns about a certain way that seems right to a man. What is the ultimate outcome of such a way?
options: The end thereof are the ways of death
It leads to great wealth
It results in long life and peace
It brings honor among men
questions.correctAnswer: The end thereof are the ways of death
questions.explanation: This verse emphasizes the dangers of trusting human judgment apart from God's guidance (Jeremiah 10:23; Isaiah 55:8-9; Romans 3:10-18; Matthew 7:13-14; James 1:5). Many paths seem right but lead to spiritual and eternal death.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 14:16, how do a wise man and a fool differ in their response to evil?
options: A wise man fears and departs from evil; a fool rages and is confident
A wise man embraces evil; a fool runs from it
Both a wise man and a fool ignore evil
A wise man rages; a fool fears
questions.correctAnswer: A wise man fears and departs from evil; a fool rages and is confident
questions.explanation: This contrasts godly reverence and avoidance of sin with foolish arrogance and rebellion (Psalm 34:14; Proverbs 3:7; Romans 16:19; James 4:6-7; 1 Corinthians 10:12). The wise act with humility and fear of God.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 14:18 say about the inheritance of the simple versus the prudent?
options: The simple inherit folly; the prudent are crowned with knowledge
The simple inherit wealth; the prudent inherit poverty
The simple inherit wisdom; the prudent inherit folly
The simple and prudent both inherit knowledge
questions.correctAnswer: The simple inherit folly; the prudent are crowned with knowledge
questions.explanation: Folly results from naivety and lack of fear of God, while prudence brings wisdom and its rewards (Psalm 111:10; Proverbs 1:7; Colossians 1:9-10; James 3:17; 2 Timothy 2:15). Knowledge is depicted as a crown, a symbol of honor and success.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 14:20, how do the poor and the rich differ in their social acceptance?
options: The poor is hated even of his own neighbour; the rich has many friends
The poor is loved by all; the rich is despised
Both poor and rich are equally loved
The poor has many friends; the rich is hated
questions.correctAnswer: The poor is hated even of his own neighbour; the rich has many friends
questions.explanation: This verse exposes social realities and the injustice toward the poor (Psalm 68:10; Proverbs 19:4; James 2:1-7; Luke 16:19-31; Matthew 25:31-46). It calls believers to mercy and justice for the marginalized.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 14:21 say about the one who despises his neighbour versus one who has mercy on the poor?
options: He that despises his neighbour sins; he that has mercy on the poor is happy
He that despises his neighbour is wise; he that has mercy on the poor is foolish
Both despise and have mercy are equal
Despising the neighbour leads to blessing; mercy leads to shame
questions.correctAnswer: He that despises his neighbour sins; he that has mercy on the poor is happy
questions.explanation: Despising others violates God's law of love and neighborliness (Leviticus 19:18; Matthew 22:39; James 2:8-13; 1 John 3:17-18; Galatians 6:10). Mercy toward the poor reflects God's heart and brings blessing.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 14:23, what is the outcome of labor compared to the talk of the lips?
options: In all labor there is profit; talk of the lips tends only to penury
Labor leads to poverty; talk leads to wealth
Both labor and talk lead to profit
Labor leads to destruction; talk leads to salvation
questions.correctAnswer: In all labor there is profit; talk of the lips tends only to penury
questions.explanation: This teaches the value of diligent work and the emptiness of idle talk (Ecclesiastes 2:24; 1 Thessalonians 4:11-12; Proverbs 12:11; James 2:14-17; Colossians 3:23-24). Faith without works is dead, and action is necessary for blessing.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 14:26 say about the fear of the LORD and its effect on confidence?
options: In the fear of the LORD is strong confidence; his children shall have a place of refuge
Fear of the LORD leads to despair and confusion
Confidence comes from wealth, not fear of the LORD
Fear of the LORD makes one weak and vulnerable
questions.correctAnswer: In the fear of the LORD is strong confidence; his children shall have a place of refuge
questions.explanation: Fear of God produces solid trust and security, as seen throughout Scripture (Psalm 112:7; Isaiah 33:6; Proverbs 3:5-6; Hebrews 10:19-22; Psalm 46:1). It provides spiritual refuge and assurance in trials.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 14:29, what is the biblical connection between being slow to anger and understanding?
options: He that is slow to wrath is of great understanding; he that is hasty exalteth folly
Quick anger leads to wisdom; slow anger leads to folly
Anger and understanding are unrelated
Being hasty in spirit is a sign of great understanding
questions.correctAnswer: He that is slow to wrath is of great understanding; he that is hasty exalteth folly
questions.explanation: Patience and self-control are marks of wisdom (Proverbs 15:18; Ecclesiastes 7:9; James 1:19-20; Galatians 5:22-23; Ephesians 4:26-27). Hastiness and uncontrolled anger lead to foolish behavior and relational damage.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 14:31 say about oppressing the poor and honoring God?
options: He that oppresseth the poor reproacheth his Maker; he that honoureth Him hath mercy on the poor
Oppressing the poor honors God; mercy on the poor dishonors Him
God is indifferent to how we treat the poor
Honoring God leads to oppressing the poor
questions.correctAnswer: He that oppresseth the poor reproacheth his Maker; he that honoureth Him hath mercy on the poor
questions.explanation: This verse connects social justice with honoring God (Deuteronomy 15:7-11; Isaiah 1:17; Matthew 25:40; James 1:27; Luke 6:20-26). Caring for the poor is an expression of true worship and reverence for God.
